It depends on how you define “resonance,” but I agree. A resonance is when a system with an intrinsic mode of oscillation is driven by an external source of energy with a matching frequency, such as when one tunes a radio to match the frequency of a particular radio transmitter.

But there is something called “vortex shedding frequency” which seems to be related to inducing the initial oscillatory mode. What there isn’t is a good explanation for the layman illustrating how the frequency is determined how the vorteces create lift forces.

I think the wind just has to put enough energy into the bridge to exceed the loss of energy to damping. It’s like a simple musical instrument, like a recorder. It has an inherent fundamental frequency for a particular hole configuration. If you blow into the mouthpiece very gently, you won’t hear a note. When you increase the force of the wind, you will reach a point where the energy input is sufficient to sustain the vibration we perceive as a note. Blowing harder doesn’t change the frequency, it just provides more energy and more volume. Is that properly called “resonance”?

This video's definition of resonance is wrong. Resonance is an inherent property of a vibrating system - it does NOT require an excitation source to be "vibrating at a similar frequency". A resonant system can be stimulated to vibrate at its resonant frequency by a single non-periodic impulse. For example, when you strike a tuning fork against a hard surface, the impact force of the collision is a single pulse of energy. The resonant vibration is a mechanical property of the tuning fork, independent of the force that excites it.

Not a resonance? Well, yes and no. More yes than no. The correct statement is that aeroelastic flutter excited a torsional resonant mode in the structure of the bridge.

The oscillations of the bridge grew because of lift forces first on top of the bridge and then on the bottom of the bridge. Those forces ~were~ driving the bridge at resonance, in exactly the same way that someone pushing on a swing at just the right time over and over causes the oscillations of the swing to grow. Had the bridge not had a resonant mode, nothing would have happened. Granted, the forces that excited the resonant torsional mode were dependent on the position of the bridge itself. But then again, someone pushing their kid on a swing only pushes when the swing is in the right position, too.

Granted, the situation is more complicated than a guitar string humming along to sound at a resonant frequency. But the resonant behavior of the bridge is central to events. The way that you build bridges that don't do this is by designing out strong resonant modes. So yes, it is incorrect to say that this is a "simple resonance." But it is far ~more~ incorrect to say it was not a resonance at all.

And yes, I read Billah and Scanlon. It's a shame I didn't get the paper to referee. You learn a lot talking about things like this. It would make fun conversation over pizza and beer. But as one of those nasty PhD physicists who really and truly does understand in quite exquisite detail what is happening here, as well as the subtle differences in how physicists and engineers think about resonance, I will continue to talk about resonance and the collapse of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge. ;-)

I sympathize with the desire to make a big, clear, sweeping claim, but I think in this case the desire has lead to overreach. You are saying the bridge collapsed due to "flutter", which is a kind of positive feedback loop in which more deflection of a surface in a wind leads to more force leads to more deflection and so on. That's a great insight. But you are also saying the bridge did NOT collapse due to resonance, which is at best misleading. The flutter runs away because there is not enough damping to take the vibrational energy imparted by the wind back out of the system. And THAT'S largely because the bridge begins vibrating at a resonant natural frequency. You can see this with your own eyes in the video: the bridge settles into a vivid standing wave pattern. The key characteristic of such a resonance--just as you say--is that it allows more and more vibrational energy to be added to the system--by the wind, in this case. So 'flutter yes, resonance no' is a bad way to think about it. Better to say that flutter fed energy into a natural resonant vibrational mode of the bridge until the bridge collapsed.

Hi! I'm a civil engineer and structural analysis is one of my favourites topics. I also happen to know a bit about wind effects on buildings an aeroelasticity so I'm going to try to shed some light here.

The video was great, but it is a bit misleading because you say that there was no vortex shedding involved in the collapse of the Tacoma Narrow bridge and that's not entirely true. In fact what caused the bridge to oscillate in first place was vortex shedding. This happened for several days and during this lapse of time the bridge would oscillate in a vertical (not torsional) mode. It was only during the last 45 minutes of its life that the bridge started to vibrate in a torsional+flexural mode due to flutter.

But had not the bridge been oscillating due to vortex shedding in first place, the aeroelastic phenomena probably would not have happened neither. This is because the flutter was probably induced by some failure of the bridge(degradation of its torsional stifness and the failure of some of the cables) during its vortex induced oscillations.

It is true that resonance is not involved during  flutter oscillations, but it is believed that some kind of resonance/amplification was present at the moment before the bridge collapsed. What caused this amplification is not well known and there is some debate around it and several theories. From what I've heard about it, the torsional motion generated a vortex wake that amplified the torsional oscillations but as I said before it is not clear and there are several mechanisms proposed in order to explain what really happened.

So to summarize, the secuence of the Tacoma Narrow's fail was this:

1. Vortex Induced Vibrations due to vortex shedding (vertical oscillations). This goes on during days.
2.Something goes down and flutter start kicking the last 45 minutes (flexural+torsional mode, no resonance involved)
3.Shit happens. The torsional oscillations amplify itself due to some mysterious mechanism (probably vortex shedding were involved but it is not clear) leading to the collapse of the bridge.

I think its a little careless to throw around gross generalizations and oversimplified explanations of what is and isn't resonance when trying to label something as a fallacy.  It's clear resonant frequencies of the bridge played a huge role in its collapse.

There is little doubt that resonance of vortex shedding caused the up and down waves that gave the bridge its nickname, Gallopin' Gertie. On the day it collapsed, a cable band slipped, almost certainly because of this motion. The slippage of the cable band led to the torsional flutter that destroyed the bridge. Torsional flutter does not require the periodic input of energy from the wind that vortex shedding does but it appears that the vortex shedding was involved in the transition from the vertical motion to the twisting motion. One can claim then that resonance did not destroy the bridge. However, if there was no resonance the cable band would not have slipped and the torsional flutter would never have started. It's self induced resonance, in that the wind provides the power but the aerodynamics of the bridge provide the periodicity that results in self-amplifying vibrations at the natural frequency. You're correct that it isn't simple externally forced linear resonance, but that's not the only kind. The paper in the description makes this conclusion in the last paragraph of section IV. "Divergence occurs when a lifting surface deflects under aerodynamic load so as to increase the applied load, or move the load so that the twisting effect on the structure is increased. The increased load deflects the structure further, which brings the structure to the limit loads and to failure. This happened to the Tacoma Narrows Bridge in Washington."

"aeroelastic phenomena arise when structural deformations induce changes on aerodynamic forces. The additional aerodynamic forces cause an increase in the structural deformations, which leads to greater aerodynamic forces in a feedback process. These interactions may become smaller until a condition of equilibrium is reached, or may diverge catastrophically if resonance occurs."

Actually the phenomenon was first identified in the 1940s, but probably not applied to bridges.  I asked a bridge designer if there is criteria for "resonance" now, but even now resonance or aeroelastic flutter in not part of structural design.  But criteria has been introduced in codes and manuals that serves to prevent/minimize this kind of effect.  Given complexity of dynamic loading, it is super-difficult to analyze dynamic resonance of complex structures, to the point of being infeasible.

As for bad bridge design, it is unlikely that complex lateral force effects were part of codes and manuals that engineers follow.  I am an architect, and only in the last 10-15 years have seen even seismic loads being part of the building code in states like new york.  If aeroelastic flutter was not part of standard criteria for bridge design, it is hard to blame the engineer.  Had the structure been stiff and "built like a brick shithouse" instead of sleek, this would not have happened.

any linear system simply scales the amplitude and adjusts the phase of an incoming wave, it does not "emit" a frequency of it's own persay. A resonant system is characterized by acting very different at a narrow range of frequencies or than it does at others. In the case of a passive system, it can never make the wave bigger, but it can be maximal (ie no loss) at what we call the resonant or natural frequency (they are the same for low levels of damping).

I like your videos. But on this video, there is one logical flaw: 

Resonant body/object doesn't require input frequencies to be exactly at, or near it's natural resonance. Examples are many: flute, violin, guitar,...

When you play guitar, you don't vibrate your finger with the resonance of the string acting upon, so this not means that wind must vibrate with the resonance of the bridge in order to excite vibrations.

Flag for example flutter on wind, but doesn't resonate at distinct frequency.
